Description: Rim sherd of Chian black-figured Animal pottery bowl; white slip; interior: reserved band at top of rim, glazed streaky black below with trace of added red and possible added white outline at bottom of sherd; exterior: black line around edge of rim; below, black-figure decoration consisting of bull (lower parts of legs and hind end missing; red on back, shoulder and belly), to right.
School/style: Sphinx and Lion style (according to Williams)
Curator's comments: According to Lemos, the bull appears only once in Black Figure Grand Style. Iconographically, it does not differ from its counterparts in the Sphinx and Lion style (both derive from Middle Wild Goat). Williams places the sherd within the Sphinx and Lion style based on the presence of bulls on other sherds in that style. The interior of vessels in the Sphinx and Lion Style are very rarely covered with a black slip. Furthermore, the bull is stylistically different from those found on Sphinx and Lion Style vases (see British Museum 1886,0401.1296; Cambridge Fitzwilliam GR.97a.1894; Boston 88.957; Oxford AN1896-1908-G.120.5). The sherd might be more appropriately placed with other Black Figure Animal Chalices. At least one bull does appear on another Black Figure Animal chalice (see British Museum 1924,1201.340).
